Yes, Augustine faced a great deal of criticism from his former colleagues after his conversion to Christianity. Prior to his conversion, Augustine was a well-respected scholar and teacher of rhetoric. His former colleagues and associates were shocked and disappointed by his conversion, and many of them criticized his new faith.

One of the main criticisms Augustine faced was that his conversion was motivated by personal gain, such as career advancement or a desire for power and influence. Some of his former associates accused him of using his newfound Christian faith to further his own interests.

Others attacked Augustine's beliefs directly, claiming that Christianity was a foolish and irrational religion, unworthy of serious consideration. Some of Augustine's critics also accused him of turning his back on the intellectual pursuits and philosophical inquiries he had previously championed.

Despite these criticisms, Augustine remained steadfast in his commitment to Christianity and continued to defend his faith through his writing and teachings. His conversion to Christianity ultimately led him to become one of the most influential figures in the development of Christian theology and philosophy.
